info.name: SEB PSD2 Payment Initiation
info.description:
StartFragment

The PSD2 payment initiation product provides seamless and efficient payment functionalities to enhance your payment services.

EndFragment  

SEB Developer Portal documentation:  
[https://developer.sebgroup.com/products/psd2-payment-initiation](https://developer.sebgroup.com/products/psd2-payment-initiation)

Github postman information:  
[openbanking/postman at master · sebgroup/openbanking · GitHub](https://desktop.postman.com/?desktopVersion=9.22.2&userId=6900617&teamId=314386)

EndFragment

item.name: Request approval for an Authorization Code

request.description: Requests a customers consent to be issued an authorization grant for access to customer owned data. This request will redirect the user to login and approve the request for the given combination of scopes and client_id. This will generate and send a one time Authorization Code to the redirect_url according to OAuth2 specifications.

item.name: Request Access Token for Authorization Code or Refresh Token

urlencoded.description: (Required) Authorization code provided by the /authorize endpoint to the redirect_uri.
(Required) The URI of the application requesting the authorization grant. is requesting this code or token to be redirected to
(Required) Type of grant to be processed.
The refresh token obtained from originally submitted authorization grant request. (Required for refresh_token grant_type)

request.description:
Allows requesting an access token following one of the flows below:
- Authorization Code (exchange code for access token)
- Refresh Token (exchange refresh token for a new access code)

The table below indicates the required parameters for each specific Grant Types. Empty cells indicate a parameter is ignored for that specific grant type.

|        | Authorization Code  | Refresh Token |
|---------------------|--------------------|------------|
| __client_id__       | required           | required   |
| __client_secret__   | required           | required   |
| __code__            | required           |            |      
| __redirect_uri__    | required           |            |
| __scope__           | optional           | optional   |
| __refresh_token__   |                    | required   |

item.name: Lists templates that correspond with available payment products

request.description:
Access the template list endpoint to find all the supported payment products in the PSD2 API. Use the template id in list to receive a partially filled-in payment initiation request. Fill in the template fields and submit it in the payments endpoint to initiate a payment.
The scope field in the template list will indicate if each template is applicable for private or corporate scope.

response.name: A template list with descriptions of the payment products.

header.description: (Required) Accepted content types.

item.name: The payment template is used so that the consumer of the API knows which fields they need to fill in when creating a payment inititation.

request.description:
Use the template id in the templates endpoint to receive a partially filled-in payment initiation request. All the field content shuld be populated with the relevant data in place of the provided instructions.
The filled-in template can then be used as payment inititation payload. The name of the template will be used in the payments endpoint when creating the payment initiation, i.e. POST /payments/swedish-domestic-private-bankgiros
The templates are static so once a template has been fetched, it can be cached on the client side and be reused for future payments.

Note that the debtor account (sender) is always an IBAN for non-corporate payment types and the creditor account is dependent on the selected template (payment product). For corporate payment products sender is always a BBAN + debtorAgentBic reference. Each template will contain specific instructions on what combination of account information is needed.
The available debtor accounts can either be obtained from the customer or by using the accounts API.

response.name: A template that is partially filled-in

header.description: (Required) Accepted content types.

variable.description: (Required) Unique identifier for a specific template. Examples; swedish-domestic-private-bankgiros, swedish-domestic-private-plusgiros, swedish-domestic-private-credit-transfers, swedish-domestic-private-own-accounts-transfers, cross-border-credit-transfers, high-value-credit-transfers etc.

item.name: Get a list of authorisations associated with this payment

header.description:
(Required) Parameter is either an optional request identification id or a payment reference identification used when initiatating a payment. Parameter is set by the third party. Duplicate value on payment reference identification is not allowed. If stated in the request it will be returned in the response.
ID of the request, unique to the call, as determined by the initiating party. Same value will be returned in each successful call. Duplicate values being used will lead to errors in payment creation.
Example value "ccae853f-4f23-47a3-bd9b-6f6e75a1d3d2"

Include in any request aimed at accessing corporate accounts or corporate payment types. This is either the 14 digit SEB identifier for the company or the 10 digit organization number. When this header is included all tasks will be performed for this corporation based on the PSU having access rights. Note that this header shall not be present when accessing payment endpoints for private accounts.

variable.description: (Required) Describes which payment product this call is in reference to. Needs to match whichever payment you are requesting information for. Example value "swedish-domestic-private-bankgiros"

request.description: Gets a list of authorisation ids, including any active or previously failed authorisations for a specific payment.

item.name: Starts a single payment authentication procedure for the end customer.

header.description:
(Required) Parameter is either an optional request identification id or a payment reference identification used when initiatating a payment. Parameter is set by the third party. Duplicate value on payment reference identification is not allowed. If stated in the request it will be returned in the response.
ID of the request, unique to the call, as determined by the initiating party. Same value will be returned in each successful call. Duplicate values being used will lead to errors in payment creation.
Example value "ccae853f-4f23-47a3-bd9b-6f6e75a1d3d2"

(Required) The IP Address of the PSU, as determined in the communication between PSU and TPP, must be provided when POST'ing a payment or authorisation. During other calls supply the value if applicable. Provided in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. Example value "129.178.88.88"

Include in any request aimed at accessing corporate accounts or corporate payment types. This is either the 14 digit SEB identifier for the company or the 10 digit organization number. When this header is included all tasks will be performed for this corporation based on the PSU having access rights. Note that this header shall not be present when accessing payment endpoints for private accounts.
(Required) Customer must be redirected to this url after payment authorization is completed. Example value "https://www.seb.se"

variable.description: (Required) Describes which payment product this call is in reference to. Needs to match whichever payment you are requesting information for. Example value "swedish-domestic-private-bankgiros"

request.description:
The payment authorization sub resource is used to sign a single payment with one signature.
When the status of the payment is "RCVD" and the status response contains a link to "startAuthorisationWithAuthenticationMethodSelection" the payment is ready for signing. The response from the "/status" call will also contain a list of "scaMethods" and the appropriate "authenticationMethodId" must be choosen and provided in the request body. There are five authentication methods for payment authorization – “bankIdQr”, “bankIdSameDevice”, “digipass”, “mobiltbankId” and “bankIdOnCard”. Authentication methods depends on customer type (Private/Corporate). 
This will create an authorization resource and the client must then get the authorisation resource in order to proceed with the signing.
In sandbox environment all signings are mocked and processed within 30 seconds automatically.

request.description:
When a customer signing is initiated, a corresponding Authorization resource will be created. The client must continuously check the progress of the ongoing signing until scaStatus is either finalized or failed.
Depending on the chosen scaMethod, the response can contain the following
* scaRedirect link for digipass, mobiltbankId and bankIdOnCard, containing the url where the PSU should be redirected in order to sign.
* autoStartToken for bankIdSameDevice, which should be used to trigger the BankId application in accordance with the Bankid relying party guidelines.
* qrData for bankIdQr, the value should be rendered as a QR code, which the PSU will scan to initiate the signing using bankid.
In the case of qrData, the client needs to call this endpoint every second to retrieve new QR code content, and then display an updated QR code to the PSU. For other scaMethods we recommend polling at most every second, and no less than every five seconds.
For scaMethods bankIdQr and bankIdSameDevice it is possible that at some point a scaRedirect link will be returned. The presence of this scaRedirect link indicates that the PSU is required to complete a second verification step to authorize the payment, and the client should redirect the PSU to the provided url.

The scaStatus field can have the following values
* started -> Signing is initialized and the PSU should sign.
* finalized -> Signing has finished succesfully.
* failed -> Signing has ended unsucessfully, i.e due to timeout or cancellation.

In sandbox environment all signings are mocked and processed within 30 seconds automatically. For redirect signing in sandbox "scaRedirect" link is not real. To trigger a second verification step in sandbox, sign a payment with an amount higher than 10 000 in any currency and the additional scaRedirect link will be present in the response.

request.description:
Cancels the addressed payment if received before cut-off time for payment product. SCA by customer is not required.
The successful response to a deletion of a payment falls into three categories depending on: payment product type; signed by customer or not; and the status in the payment process system.
* Payment is deleted immediately. This response for this is the http code 204 No Content.
* Payment is deleted asynchronosly. The response for this is the http code 202 Accepted. The client must then check the status of the payment. If the payment status switches to CANC (within a few minutes), then the payment has been deleted.
* Payment cannot be deleted. The response for this is the http code 202 Accepted. The client must then check the status of the payment. If the payment status does not switch to CANC (within a few minutes), then the payment cannot be cancelled. Additional delete requests will not cancel the payment.
* On some errors - such as trying to delete an already rejected payment a 400 Input Error status can be received. See responses.

response.name: Deletion request was accepted. Please check the status of the payment. Transaction status CANC indicates that the payment is successfully deleted.

request.description:
During the payment initiation the payment systems will process payment data asynchronously.
The consumer of the API must continuously check the status of the payment to make sure that the payment is ready for the next step in the payment process.
The status request uses the payment id value that was returned in the Location header when posting the payment data.
The transaction status can have the following states
* RCVD, Received, The payment has been received by SEB. To determine if payment is ready for signing, check the links block. Recommended polling interval is 5 seconds;
* RCVD + link, Received, If "startAuthorisationWithAuthenticationMethodSelection" link is shown, the payment system has validated the payment. Please post authenticationMethodId to suitable authorisations endpoint to continue payment flow.
* ACTC, AcceptedTechnicalValidation, AcceptedCustomerProfile, The payment initiation is signed and stored for execution and should be executed on the desired execution date.
* ACSC, AcceptedSettlementCompleted,  The payment has been executed on the desired date.
* CANC, Cancelled, The payment has been cancelled and will not be executed
* RJCT, Rejected, The payment initiation failed. Additional information may be supplied to explain why the payment could not be made. A failed payment cannot be corrected, it has to be posted again as a new payment.
Payments must be signed by the customer (i.e. through Mobilt BankID) before the payment is executed.
This step can be initiated once the associated authentication link is visible in the status endpoint.
The payments can either be signed one by one by creating an authorisations sub-resource under the payment; or multiple payments
can be signed at once by creating a signing basket (with a group of payment ids) and then creating an authorisations sub-resource
under the signing basket.

request.description:
Creates a payment initiation from the provided information.
Corporate payment initiations can only be performed if the "PSU-Corporate-Id" header is set.
In production the call also needs to come from a corporate TPP client-id.
The payment API accepts different kinds of payment instructions.
Templates are used to help the consumer to select the right payment product and they can be retrieved from the templates API.
Access the template list endpoint to find all the supported payment products, 'GET /templates'.
Note that the debtor account (sender) for private payments is always an IBAN and the creditor account type is dependent on the selected template (payment product).
The available debtor accounts can either be obtained from the customer or by using the accounts API.
The "Location" header of the response will contain the URL pointing to the newly created resource.
'Location → /payments/swedish-domestic-private-credit-transfers/STOHYD01180208082256128737000001'
The response will also include the paymentId as a field in the body.
During the payment initiation the payment systems will process the payment data asynchronously.
The client must continuously check the status of the payment to make sure that the payment is ready for the next step in the payment process.
Transfers between customers own accounts will be processed directly and queued for execution on the requested execution-date.
Other payments must be signed by the customer (e.g. through Mobilt BankID) before the payment is executed.
Signing can be initiated once the associated authentication link is visible in the status endpoint.
The payments can either be signed one by one by creating an authorisations sub-resource under the payment; or multiple payments
can be signed at once by creating a signing basket (with a group of payment ids) and then creating an authorisations sub-resource
under the signing basket.
Sandbox environment; the mock will reset all data each sunday at midnight, a customer can also reset their own data by calling the reset endpoint.

item.name: Selects a SCA (Strong Customer Authentication) method and creates an authorization for payments in the basket. The end customer should sign the payment using this method.

header.description:
(Required) Parameter is either an optional request identification id or a payment reference identification used when initiatating a payment. Parameter is set by the third party. Duplicate value on payment reference identification is not allowed. If stated in the request it will be returned in the response.
ID of the request, unique to the call, as determined by the initiating party. Same value will be returned in each successful call. Duplicate values being used will lead to errors in payment creation.
Example value "ccae853f-4f23-47a3-bd9b-6f6e75a1d3d2"

(Required) The IP Address of the PSU, as determined in the communication between PSU and TPP, must be provided when POST'ing a payment or authorisation. During other calls supply the value if applicable. Provided in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. Example value "129.178.88.88"

Include in any request aimed at accessing corporate accounts or corporate payment types. This is either the 14 digit SEB identifier for the company or the 10 digit organization number. When this header is included all tasks will be performed for this corporation based on the PSU having access rights. Note that this header shall not be present when accessing payment endpoints for private accounts.
(Required) Customer must be redirected to this url after payment authorization is completed. Example value "https://www.seb.se"

request.description:
Selects and starts the authentication procedure for the end customer. The selected SCA method id is sent in the request. There are five authentication methods for payment authorization – “bankIdQr”, “bankIdSameDevice”, “digipass”, “mobiltbankId” and “bankIdOnCard”. Authentication methods depends on customer type (Private/Corporate). If the basket contains any rejected payments or only unsignable payments the request will be rejected.
Payment ids that are about to signed will be returned in the response and this list may differ from all the payments in the payment basket. Payments that are already in the middle of the signing process and already signed payments will be excluded from the created authorization resource. As such the created authorization might not contain all payments in the basket, so please check the "paymentIds" field. 
This will create an authorization resource and the client must then get the authorisation resource in order to proceed with the signing.
In sandbox environment all signings are mocked and processed within 30 seconds automatically.

request.description:
When a customer signing is initiated, a corresponding Authorization resource will be created. The client must continuously check the progress of the ongoing signing until scaStatus is either finalized or failed. 

Payment ids that are about to signed will be returned in the response. Payments that are already in the middle of the signing process and already signed payments will be excluded from the created authorization resource.
As such the created authorization might not contain all payments in the basket, so please check the "paymentIds" field.
Depending on the chosen scaMethod, the response can contain the following
* scaRedirect link for digipass, mobiltbankId and bankIdOnCard, containing the url where the PSU should be redirected in order to sign.
* autoStartToken for bankIdSameDevice, which should be used to trigger the BankId application in accordance with the Bankid relying party guidelines.
* qrData for bankIdQr, the value should be rendered as a QR code, which the PSU will scan to initiate the signing using bankid.
In the case of qrData, the client needs to call this endpoint every second to retrieve new QR code content, and then display an updated QR code to the PSU. For other scaMethods we recommend polling at most every second, and no less than every five seconds.
For scaMethods bankIdQr and bankIdSameDevice it is possible that at some point a scaRedirect link will be returned. The presence of this scaRedirect link indicates that the PSU is required to complete a second verification step to authorize the payment, and the client should redirect the PSU to the provided url.
The scaStatus field can have the following values
* started -> Signing is initialized and the PSU should sign.
* finalized -> Signing has finished succesfully.
* failed -> Signing has ended unsucessfully, i.e due to timeout or cancellation.

In sandbox environment all signings are mocked and processed within 30 seconds automatically. For redirect signing in sandbox "scaRedirect" link is not real. To trigger a second verification step in sandbox, sign a payment with an amount higher than 10 000 in any currency and the additional scaRedirect link will be present in the response.

request.description:
Returns the which payments are part of the signing basket and the overall transaction status.
The transaction status can be
* RJCT - This basket can no longer be used to sign for the payments (e.g. it contains a payment that has been rejected). Please create a new basket with the relevant payments.
* RCVD - The basket is ready for signing.
* ACTC - All payments in the basket are signed and will be executed.

item.name: Starts a multiple payment authentication procedure for the end customer. Creates a signing basket containing payment ids in the request body.

header.description:
(Required) Parameter is either an optional request identification id or a payment reference identification used when initiatating a payment. Parameter is set by the third party. Duplicate value on payment reference identification is not allowed. If stated in the request it will be returned in the response.
ID of the request, unique to the call, as determined by the initiating party. Same value will be returned in each successful call. Duplicate values being used will lead to errors in payment creation.
Example value "ccae853f-4f23-47a3-bd9b-6f6e75a1d3d2"

Include in any request aimed at accessing corporate accounts or corporate payment types. This is either the 14 digit SEB identifier for the company or the 10 digit organization number. When this header is included all tasks will be performed for this corporation based on the PSU having access rights. Note that this header shall not be present when accessing payment endpoints for private accounts.

request.description: The signing basket is used to sign multiple payments with one signature. First create a signing basket containing the payment ids that should be signed. The response will contain a list of available SCA methods that can be used to sign the payments. Then create an authorisation sub resource using the selected payment SCA method.

response.name: A signing basket is created for provided payment-ids.

(Required) Contains the Bearer Token for OAuth 2.0. Example value "Bearer eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJSUzI1NiIsIng1d_etc"

When this header is included all tasks will be performed for this corporation based on the PSU having access rights. Note that this header shall not be present when accessing payment endpoints for private accounts.
Same value that was provided in the request.

item.name: Returns true or false to indicate if funds are available.

header.description: (Required) ID of the request as set by the initiating party, a unique value should be used for each request. Same value will be returned as a header with each successful call. Suggested for use with GUIDs, but any string is valid.

Include in any request aimed at accessing corporate accounts or corporate payment types. This is the 14 digit SEB identifier for the company. When this header is included all tasks will be performed for this corporation based on the PSU having access rights. Note that this header shall not be present when checking fund confirmation for private accounts.
The IP Address of the PSU, as determined in the communication between PSU and TPP, can be provided if applicable. Provided in either IPv4 or IPv6 format. Example value "129.178.88.88"
Send in an expected user-id to verify that the used Authorization token matches the user expected. Can be set to 10 or 12 digit personal number, or a 6 digit XID

Checks if the correct type of user is checked in. PERSNR checks that PSU is logged in using a personal number (can still be either private or corporate user), whereas XID checks that a SEB corporate user is logged in using an SEB specific ID
The forwarded header field of the HTTP request between PSU and TPP, if available. Example value "8080"

The forwarded header field of the HTTP request between PSU and TPP, if available. Example value "Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 6.1; Win64; x64) AppleWebKit/537.36 (KHTML, like Gecko) Chrome/66.0.3359.181 Safari/537.36"
The forwarded Geo Location of the corresponding HTTP request between PSU and TPP if available. See RFC2426. Example value "GEO:52.506931,13.144558"
The forwarded header field of the HTTP request between PSU and TPP, if available. Example value "text/html,application/xhtml+xml,application/xml;q=0.9,image/webp,image/apng,*/*;q=0.8"
The forwarded header field of the HTTP request between PSU and TPP, if available. Example value "ISO-8859-1"
The forwarded header field of the HTTP request between PSU and TPP, if available. Example value "gzip, deflate"
The forwarded header field of the HTTP request between PSU and TPP, if available. Example value "en-US,en;q=0.9,sv;q=0.8"
HTTP method used at the PSU – TPP interface, if available. Example value "POST"
UUID (Universally Unique Identifier) for a device, which is used by the PSU, if available. Example value "05a18f38-c218-4d1c-a9d0-ac36763580e1"

request.description:
Checks if funds are available on the account specified in the request body. The amount is checked against the account balance (considering booked, reserved and pending amounts as well as any credit limit).

A positive response does not automatically mean that a corresponding payment will be accepted as product specific limits, other payments initiations or other factors may affect payment initiation. The fund confirmation service does not reserve any amount on the account. This service may only be invoked as part of a ongoing payment initiation.
To check funds on a corporate account set the PSU-Corporate-ID header. In production this will need to be combined with using a corporate linked client-id.

response.name: Information about availability of funds for the account.

item.name: Starts a single standing order authentication procedure for the end customer.

header.description:
(Required) ID of the request as set by the initiating party, a unique value should be used for each request. Same value will be returned as a header with each successful call. Suggested for use with GUIDs, but any string is valid.
Example value "ccae853f-4f23-47a3-bd9b-6f6e75a1d3d2"
(Required) Customer must be redirected to this url after payment authorization is completed. Example value "https://www.seb.se"

variable.description: (Required) The id that is created for the standing order. Observe that this is actually not a payment, but an instruction to generate monthly payments.

request.description:
The authorization sub resource is used to sign a single standing order with one signature.
When the status of the standing order is "RCVD" and the status response contains a link to "startAuthorisationWithAuthenticationMethodSelection" the standing order is ready for signing. The response from the "/status" call will also contain a list of "scaMethods" and the appropriate "authenticationMethodId" must be choosen and provided in the request body. There are five authentication methods for standing order authorization - “bankIdQr”, “bankIdSameDevice”, “digipass”, “mobiltbankId” and “bankIdOnCard”.
This will create an authorization resource and the client must then get the authorisation resource in order to proceed with the signing.
The response from this method will contain a psuMessage field, which should be shown to the end customer so that they can initiate the correct signing action. The field tppMessages will contain messages directed at the client informing them about actions to facilitate signing. For BankID authentication methods there is no further actions for client. In case of signing with Digipass, "scaRedirect" link is provided in response. Client must redirect customer to that link, or link must followed by customer to finish signing.
In sandbox environment all signings are mocked and processed within 30 seconds automatically. For redirect signing in sandbox "scaRedirect" link is not real. To trigger a second verification step in sandbox, sign a payment with an amount higher than 10 000 in any currency and the additional scaRedirect link will be present in the response.

response.name: Authorization is started using the provided authorization method.

Example value "ccae853f-4f23-47a3-bd9b-6f6e75a1d3d2"

(Required) Contains the Bearer Token for OAuth 2.0.
Example value "Bearer eyJ0eXAiOiJKV1QiLCJhbGciOiJSUzI1NiIsIng1d_etc"
(Required) Customer must be redirected to this url after payment authorization is completed. Example value "https://www.seb.se"

request.description:
When a customer signing is initiated, a corresponding Authorization resource will be created. The client must continuously check the progress of the ongoing signing until scaStatus is either finalized or failed.
Depending on the chosen scaMethod, the response can contain the following
* scaRedirect link for digipass, mobiltbankId and bankIdOnCard, containing the url where the PSU should be redirected in order to sign.
* autoStartToken for bankIdSameDevice, which should be used to trigger the BankId application in accordance with the Bankid relying party guidelines.
* qrData for bankIdQr, the value should be rendered as a QR code, which the PSU will scan to initiate the signing using bankid.
In the case of qrData, the client needs to call this endpoint every second to retrieve new QR code content, and then display an updated QR code to the PSU. For other scaMethods we recommend polling at most every second, and no less than every five seconds.
For scaMethods bankIdQr and bankIdSameDevice it is possible that at some point a scaRedirect link will be returned. The presence of this scaRedirect link indicates that the PSU is required to complete a second verification step to authorize the payment, and the client should redirect the PSU to the provided url.
The scaStatus field can have the following values
* started -> Signing is initialized and the PSU should sign.
* finalized -> Signing has finished succesfully.
* failed -> Signing has ended unsucessfully, i.e due to timeout or cancellation.

In sandbox environment all signings are mocked and processed within 30 seconds automatically. For redirect signing in sandbox "scaRedirect" link is not real.

request.description:
Cancels the addressed periodic payment if received before cut-off time for payment product. SCA by customer is not required.
The successful response to a deletion of a periodic payment falls into three categories depending on: periodic payment product type; signed by customer or not; and the status in the payment process system.
* Payment is deleted immediately. This response for this is the http code 204 No Content.
* Payment is deleted asynchronosly. The response for this is the http code 202 Accepted. The client must then check the status of the payment. If the payment status switches to CANC (within a few minutes), then the payment has been deleted.
* On some errors - such as trying to delete an already rejected periodic payment a 400 Input Error status can be received. See responses.

response.name: Deletion request was accepted. Please check the status of the payment. Transaction status CANC indicates that the payment is successfully deleted.

request.description:
During the standing order initiation the payment systems will process standing order data asynchronously. The consumer of the API must continuously check the status of the standing order to make sure that it is ready for the next step in the process. The status request uses the payment id value that was returned in the Location header when posting the standing order.
The transaction status can have the following states
* RCVD, Received, The standing order has been received by SEB. To determine if standing order is ready for signing, check the links block. Recommended polling interval is 5 seconds;
* RCVD + link, Received, If "startAuthorisationWithAuthenticationMethodSelection" link is shown, the payment system has validated the standing order. Please post authenticationMethodId to suitable authorisations endpoint to continue flow.
* ACTC, AcceptedTechnicalValidation, The standing order is signed and stored, it should be generate payments periodicly from the requested start date.
* RJCT, Rejected, The standing order initiation failed. Additional information may be supplied to explain why the standing order could not be created.
Standing orders must be signed by the customer (i.e. through Mobilt BankID) before they are stored. This step can be initiated once the associated authentication link is visible in the status endpoint.

request.description:
Creates a standing order, which will generate monthly periodic payments for the customer. The standing orders are only applicable for private customers and only for domestic transfers within Sweden. The payment product must be set to either swedish-domestic-private-credit-transfers or swedish-domestic-private-own-accounts-transfers.
The "Location" header of the response will contain the URL pointing to the newly created standing order.
During the standing order initiation the payment systems will process the initiation data asynchronously. The client must continuously check the status to make sure that the standing order is ready for the next step in the process.
Standing orders for transfers between customers own accounts will be processed directly and does not need signing. Standing orders for other transfers must be signed by the customer (e.g. through Mobilt BankID) before the standing order is stored. Signing can be initiated once the associated authentication link is visible in the status endpoint.
A standing order that is created by a TPP is not visible to other TPPs. The standing order can be viewed and revoked by the TPP that created it. Please note that the resulting payments that are generated by a standing order are owned by the customer, the payment will not be associated with the TPP in any way. The generated payments are visible in the accounts API.
Sandbox environment; the mock will reset all data each sunday at midnight, a customer can also reset their own data by calling the reset endpoint listed with the payment initiation API.
